body:
New Bills, Acts, and Vetoes pages are created once a year before session starts. https://governor.hawaii.gov/2020-bills/ https://governor.hawaii.gov/2020-bills/2020-acts/ https://governor.hawaii.gov/2020-bills/2020-vetoes/ This is an image of the 2020 Bills page. The following instructions will explain how to add a new 2021 Bills page. Create two new WordPress categories First create 2 new categories. These new categories will be added to the new pages we create later. Open the Categories page. This is a list of the current categories. You must add 2 new categories, 2021 Acts and 2021 Vetoes. To create the new 2021 Acts category, fill out the Name and Slug fields. See the yellow-highlighted fields below. The name is how it appears on the site. The name may contain spaces. The “slug” is the URL-friendly version of the name. It is usually all lowercase and contains only letters, numbers, and hyphens, NO SPACES. Create the 2021 Vetoes category. Follow the steps above, changing “acts” to “vetoes”. Here is an image of the new categories. Remember the ID’s of the new categories. We’ll need the ID’s when we create the 2021 pages (next steps). In this example, the 2021 Acts ID is 105 and the 2021 Vetoes ID is 106. Create three new WordPress pages We must create 3 new WordPress pages. 2021 Bills 2021 Acts 2021 Vetoes 1. Create the Bills page First create the 2021 Bills page. Use the 2020 Bills page as a template for the 2021 Bills page. Copy and paste the 2020 HTML code to create the new 2021 page. Click the left-menu item to open the list of WordPress pages. There are over 100 pages. Click the next-page button (highlighted yellow below) until you see 2020 Bills in the list. Click on the 2020 Bills title. After clicking the title name, the “Edit Page” is opened and the page details are displayed. Copy the 2020 Bills HTML code highlighted yellow below. To see the HTML code, set the viewing mode to “Text” mode instead of “Visual” mode. The following is the 2020 HTML code.

  • Acts

  • Bills signed by the Governor

  • Vetoes

Create a new page by clicking the Add New button or click the Pages Add New menu item. or The Add New Page window is opened. Enter the title “2020 Bills” into the title box. Enter the 2020 HTML code in the editor box. The HTML is the code you copied in a previous step. Update the code in the editor box. Change all instances of 2020 to 2021. Change only complete instances of 2020. Do NOT change any %20. If you change any stand-alone 20, the hyperlink URL will be incorrect. A URL is not allowed to have spaces, so a special code, %20, was invented by the internet inventors. It’s all magic. Click the Publish button to save the page and make the page available to the public. This is the final 2021 Bills page. 2. Create the Acts page After creating the 2021 Bills page, create the 2021 Acts page. Use the 2020 Acts page as a template for the 2021 Acts page. Copy and paste the 2020 Acts HTML code to create the new 2021 page. Open the list of WordPress pages. Find the 2020 Acts page. The title of the Acts page has a leading em-dash. Click on the 2020 Acts title. After clicking the title, the “Edit Page” is opened and the page details are displayed. Copy the 2020 Acts HTML code highlighted yellow below. Click the Add New button. This is the 2020 Acts code: [scp category="94" num_posts="20" order_by="date" order_by_option="DESC" show_preview="1" read_more="Read More" use_pagination="1"] The “Add New Page” window is opened. Enter title “2021 Acts”, HTML code, and set the parent to “2021 Bills”. Update the category to new Acts category ID that you generated in a previous step. In this example, the new Acts category ID is 105. Click the publish button to save the page and make the page available to the public. This is the final 2021 Acts page. 3. Create the Vetoes page After creating the 2021 Bills and 2021 Acts pages, create the 2021 Vetoes page. Use the 2020 Vetoes page as a template for the 2021 Vetoes page. Copy and paste the 2020 Vetoes HTML code to create the new 2021 page. Open the list of WordPress pages. Find the 2020 Vetoes page. The title of the Vetoes page has a leading em-dash. Click on the 2020 Vetoes title. After clicking the title, the “Edit Page” is opened and the page details are displayed. Copy the 2020 Vetoes HTML code highlighted yellow below. Click the Add New button. This is the 2020 Vetoes code: For a full report from the Hawai’i State Legislature, click HERE. [scp category="95" num_posts="20" order_by="date" order_by_option="DESC" show_preview="1" read_more="Read More" use_pagination="1"] The “Add New Page” window is opened. Enter title “2021 Vetoes”, HTML code, and set the parent to “2021 Bills”. Update the category to new Vetoes category ID that you generated in a previous step. In this example, the new Vetoes category ID is 106. Click the publish button to save the page and make the page available to the public. This is the final 2021 Vetoes page. Add News navigation menu item In the News page, https://governor.hawaii.gov/category/newsroom/, the right-side navigation menu has the Bills listed by year. Each year when session begins, we add a new menu option for the new year. After creating the 2021 Bills, 2021 Acts and 2021 Vetoes pages, we add a menu item to the right-side Newsroom navigation menu. To add to the Newsroom right-side menu, select the Appearance/Menus option. Select a menu to edit from the dropdown: Newsroom. Select the checkbox for page 2021 Bills. Click the Add to Menu button. After clicking the Add to Menu button, the new 2021 Bills menu item appears at the bottom of the menu structure. “Drag and drop” the 2021 Bills menu option to the top. Now that the 2021 Bills menu option is in place, click the Save Menu button. The new Newsroom right-side navigation menu will look like this: Post new acts and vetoes During Session, post new acts and vetoes. Look at a 2020 post to see the content format. There are multiple ways to start a new post. Start a new post. Be sure to select a category from the category list on the right. If you forget to select a category, the post will appear on the main news page. To fix the missing category problem, edit the post, unselect the Main category and select the correct Act or Veto category. Notes Historical webpage - 2018 Bills - the format has changed for 2019.

  • Acts

  • Bills pending Governor’s action

  • Bills signed by the Governor

  • Vetoes

  • Request a Bill Signing Ceremony

  • Acts

  • Bills signed by the Governor

  • Vetoes

body:
Note: The people names, street addresses, telphone numbers, and email addresses in the following images are randomized randomness.
Flag requests list The first window is a list of flag requests. There are 2 tabs, Open and Closed.
There are many more closed requests than open requests.
Edit request Click on a Name in the list to open the Details window. See image below. To edit the request details, click the button at the window bottom. The Edit button will open the Edit window. Update the data and click the button. Add a note On the Details window, click the button to add notes to the request. Enter the note in the popup textbox highlighted in the image below with yellow. Click the button. Your new note appears on the right side of the window. Add attachment Generate a certificate signed by the Governor to be saved into the GovCRM database. Click the button to open the Attachments popup window. Click the button to open the file selector. After selecting a file, click the button to upload the file. A note is automatically added to the list on the right. A Flag Request may have more than one attachment files.
Close request To close a request, click the button. The button will open the Close Flag Request popup window.
Select a reason for closing the request.
Flag flown and sent (default) No flag Declined (we declined the request) Enter optional notes into the Notes textbox.
Click the button.
After closing request, the status is updated and notes are displayed on the right.
Reports Select a report from the list of reports by checking the radio button. Currently, Flag Requests has only one report. If you want more reports, ask your application development team.
Enter the report starting date and report ending date directly into the input boxes Or click the calendar dropdown button for the calendar date picker. The default dates are the beginning of this year and the end of this month. Click the button. The report output is an Excel file downloaded to your Downloads folder.
In this report, cell A2 is the range of dates when the request was closed.
In this report, cell N1 is the report generation date.
Notes The page title on the tab is the Honoree’s last name.
You may search thru the Closed requests. This is the same as using control-F but is nicer.
Selecting the Flag Requests menu option will display the Flag Requests List.

The genesis of that mission and of DARPA itself dates to the launch of Sputnik in 1957, and a commitment by the United States that, from that time forward, it would be the initiator and not the victim of strategic technological surprises. Working with innovators inside and outside of government, DARPA has repeatedly delivered on that mission, transforming revolutionary concepts and even seeming impossibilities into practical capabilities. The ultimate results have included not only game-changing military capabilities such as precision weapons and stealth technology, but also such icons of modern civilian society such as the Internet, automated voice recognition and language translation, and Global Positioning System receivers small enough to embed in myriad consumer devices. Images are resized to fit your screen. To see a larger image, right-click the image and select “Open image in new tab”.
During session, we must update the bill count on the homepage.
Start of Session Before you update the single page section containing the bills signed counter, you should create the Acts and Vetoes pages. Click here.
Update the BILLS SIGNED AND VETOED section At the beginning of each session, we need to update the text in the BILLS SIGNED AND VETOED section on the homepage.
Update this section: with new 2020 values: Sign-in to WordPress. Click the button in the left-side menu. Click on title BILLS SIGNED OR VETOED. The title is highlighted in red below. The single page section content is displayed. See the image below.
Your display may look different from the image below because of your display monitor size and word-wrap. To see the content in text mode, switch from Visual mode to Text mode by clicking the Text tab. In the image below, the Text tab is highlighted in red. Update the dates.
Update the current year. Update the bill count. Update the Intent to Veto deadline. Update the Final Approval deadline. Update the URL’s.
Update the Acts and Vetoes button hyperlinks to the current links. You should have already created the new 2020 Acts page and 2020 Vetoes page. Usually you would only need to update the year in the hyperlinks. Display the buttons.
To enable the Submit Comments on Legislation and Request a Bill Signing Ceremony buttons, remove the “HTML comment tags” from the html text. Remove the text that looks like <!-- or --> The image below displays the location of the “HTML comment tags”. The image has 4 red boxes. Delete the text in the red boxes labeld Comment tag. After you have updated the single page section, the text looks like this:
Click the update button. This is the webpage after updates.
Enable the Comments on Legislation page In the interim, the Comments on Legislation page is set to private.
When the Submit Comments on Legislation button is enabled (see above), set this page Visibility to Public. The URL for the Comments on Legislation page is https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/comments-on-legislation/. Click Edit Select Public Click Ok Click Publish Done Enable the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page In the interim, the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page is set to private.
When the Request A Bill Signing Ceremony button is enabled (see above), set this page Visibility to Public. The URL for the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page is https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/bill-signing-ceremony-request/. Click Edit Select Public Click Ok Click Publish Done During Session During session, update the bill count as the Governor signs bills. To see the content in text mode, switch from Visual mode to Text mode by clicking the Text tab. Click the Update button. End of Session After the Final Approval date, hide the Submit Comments on Legislation button, hide the Request a Bill Signing Ceremony button, disable the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page, and disable the Comments on Legislation page.
To hide the buttons, insert the “HTML comment tags” before and after the button’s html code.
These are sample “HTML comment tags”. Be careful. Code must be correct and precise. Code is techy.
<!-- Stuff to hide --> This image displays the location of the “HTML comment tags”. Insert the code in the location indicated by the red lines. Disable the Comments on Legislation page Set the Comments on Legislation page’s visibility to private. https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/comments-on-legislation/ Click Edit Select Private Click Ok Click Publish Done Disable the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page Set the Bill Signing Ceremony Request page’s visibility to private. https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/bill-signing-ceremony-request/ Click Edit Select Private Click Ok Click Publish Done Remove the Contact Us tiles On the Contact Us page, remove the Comments on Legislation tile and the Bill Signing Ceremony Request tile. Click here for instructions. Notes Repeat all this again next year.

GovCRM Developer setup Install Visual Studio 2022 https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/
Select options ASP.NET and web development .NET desktop development .NET Framework project and item templates (Individual components) Install a desktop SQL database LocalDb
The Visual Studio 2022 default installation will install LocalDb. If you installed Visual Studio 2022, you are done. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/database-engine/configure-windows/sql-server-express-localdb SQL Server
If you prefer SQL Server, you can install SQL Server Developer Edition
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/sql-server/sql-server-downloads Set the server authentication to SQL Server and Windows Authentication mode If using Hyper-V:
Add firewall setting: Port TCP 1433 Allow. Open Sql Server Configuration Manager. Enable TCP/IP protocol. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/sql-server-2016/ms187892(v=sql.130) Install SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/ssms/download-sql-server-management-studio-ssms
To connect to a LocalDB database, use server name (LocalDB)\MSSQLLocalDB with Windows authentication. To connect to a SQL Server database, use server name yourcomputername or localhost with Windows authentication. Join the Microsoft 365 Developer Program https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/dev-program
Choose your tenant name wisely. There is no way to change it.
Includes 25 user licenses for development purposes. Access core Microsoft 365 workloads and capabilities including: SharePoint, Exchange, and more.
Set up your new Microsoft 365 Developer subscription Tips & Tricks https://youtu.be/DhhpJ1UjbJ0
Clone C# project $ git clone https://yoshiakiiinuma@dev.azure.com/yoshiakiiinuma/GovHawaiiCS/_git/GovHawaiiCS $ cd GovHawaiiCS $ nuget.exe restore $ cp GovHawaiiCS/Web.config.base GovHawaiiCS/Web.config Edit Web.config according to your environment
If you update any nuget packages, copy the nuget changes in Web.config to Web.config.base.
$ git clone https://yoshiakiiinuma@dev.azure.com/yoshiakiiinuma/GovHawaiiCRMWebJob/_git/GovHawaiiCRMWebJob $ nuget.exe restore Edit app.config according to your environment. Remove your edits before committing app.config with git.
DEV/TEST Governor’s Website Add to your hosts file

The Commemorative Messages Admin (CM-Admin) staff person must assign GovCRM roles to Commemorative Messages staff. To be a CM-Admin, your IT administrator must assign you to Active Directory (AD) security group GovOfficeCRMCMAdmin. A list of all AD security groups are here.
Open the Admin page.
Select the Users and User Roles option.
Add new user Click the Create New User button.
Application User data fields:
Username - Required - User’s email address. This is the magic key. The Username MUST match the user’s email address. Last Name First Name Middle Name Display Name - Required - First name plus last name. Initials - Required - This can be a nickname or first name. Email - Required - Must match the Username. Telephone - Required - Required but not used. (yet) Island - Required Time Zone On the right-side of the screen are GovCRM roles.
Boards and Commisssion User Casework User Commemorative Message Admin Commemorative Message Assign New messages Commemorative Message Assign when Auto-pen PDF is uploaded Commemorative Message Assign when OAHU Auto-pen PDF is uploaded Commemorative Message Assign when PDF is uploaded for emailing Commemorative Message Coordinator Commemorative Message Drafter Commemorative Message Editor Commemorative Message Printer Commemorative Message Proofer Commemorative Message Router Commemorative Message Supervisor Commemorative Message User Governor Events User Legislative Comments User Role CM Router (CM) Commemorative Message or Proclamation or Military Request
(CM-Router) Role: Commemorative Message Router
(CM-Coordinator) Role: Commemorative Message Coordinator
(CM-Supervisor) Role: Commemorative Message Supervisor The CM-Router approves New CM requests. Approval will automatically send out an “Approval” email to the constituent. The Approve button is only visible to the CM-Router.
The other buttons are visible to roles CM-Coordinator and CM-Supervisor, but not the Approval button.
TODO: The coordinator or supervisor can see the Decline button. Is this right?
Role CM Drafter (CM) Commemorative Message or Proclamation or Military Request
(CM-Router) Role: Commemorative Message Router
(CM-Coordinator) Role: Commemorative Message Coordinator
(CM-Supervisor) Role: Commemorative Message Supervisor
(CM-Drafter) Role: Commemorative Message Drafter The CM-Router/CM-Coordinator/CM-Supervisor assigns a staffer to write the message. The CM-Router/CM-Coordinator/CM-Supervisor can only assign writers if the staffer is assigned role Commemorative Message Drafter.
The CM-Router/CM-Coordinator/CM-Supervisor clicks the Draft button. A dialog pops up with the Writers in the dropdown list. Staffers assigned role Commemorative Message Drafter appear in the dropdown list.
Developer note: This is the only place where CMDRAFT is used.
Role CM Printer Someone has to print the Proclamation on the fancy 11x15 paper. That would be the CM-Printer.
Developer note: This is the only place where CMPRINT is used.
Edit user

body:
This will show how to add or remove tiles from the Contact Us page. Add tile Open the Contact Us edit page. Add code for new tile. Enable the tile’s linked-to page. Remove tile Open the Contact Us edit page. Delete the tile code. Disable the tile’s linked-to page. Contact us Constituents submit comments or requests using the Contact Us page of the Governor’s website, https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/. The Contact Us webpage contains several tiles. The number of tiles will vary, depending on the needs of the office. This image shows 9 tiles. Sometimes there are 8 tiles, other times there are 10 tiles. WordPress pages Open WordPress. Click the left-menu item to open the list of WordPress pages. There are over 100 pages. Click the image of next page button next-page button (highlighted yellow below) until you see Contact Us in the list. To add or remove a tile, we edit the Contact Us page. Click the Contact Us title to open the editing page. The page ID is 14. How to add a new tile To add a new tile, add code to the existing Contact Us content. This is the before content for 8 tiles.
CONTACT THE GOVERNOR With your concerns or comments. REQUEST A COMMEMORATIVE MESSAGE To recognize an occasion, organization or individual. REQUEST A MEETINGFor a personal meeting, group or media interview. INVITE THE GOVERNOR TO AN EVENTRequest the Governor to attend your event. STATE CAPITOL TOURS Tour information SUBMIT A FLAG REQUEST To fly your flag above the Capitol and receive a Certificate of Authenticity. UIPA REQUEST Information to make a Uniform Information Practices Act request. GENERAL INFORMATIONGeneral contact details and links to related sites.
In this example, add the following Comments on Legislation tile code into the area. COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. Click the preview button to preview the updates. If the preview looks good, click the to publish the updates. The final result. The result has the tiles arranged oddly. We can make the arrangement nicer by adding the following code to the page content at the area. This style code must appear before the tile code. This is the after content for 9 tiles.
COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. CONTACT THE GOVERNOR With your concerns or comments. REQUEST A COMMEMORATIVE MESSAGE To recognize an occasion, organization or individual. REQUEST A MEETINGFor a personal meeting, group or media interview. INVITE THE GOVERNOR TO AN EVENTRequest the Governor to attend your event. STATE CAPITOL TOURS Tour information SUBMIT A FLAG REQUEST To fly your flag above the Capitol and receive a Certificate of Authenticity. UIPA REQUEST Information to make a Uniform Information Practices Act request. GENERAL INFORMATIONGeneral contact details and links to related sites.
After adding the style code, this is the final version. Enable the linked page If clicking a tile opens a WordPress page, you must change the page’s visibility to public. If you fail to change the visibility, you’ll get a 404 page not found error. The page visibility value determines if a page may be viewed by the public. The next image shows the page visibility is set to private. If a page’s visibility is set to private, the public cannot see the page and will get a 404 page not found error. To make a page available to the public, set the page’s visibility to public. Click Edit. Click Edit. Check Public. Click OK. Click Update. The page visibility is now set to public. The public can see the page. How to remove a tile In this example, we will remove the first tile in the image below, the Comments Regarding Judicial Nominees tile. To remove the first tile, delete the code in the red box shown below. Then click the preview button. The tiles will re-arrange themselves. The result is the image below. The tiles are not aligned nicely. Let’s do more editing to fix that. To prettify the page and align the tiles, delete the CSS code in the red box shown below. This CSS code overrides the CSS in the theme file *styles.css*. By removing this CSS, the webpage reverts back to the theme's default CSS. The default CSS has thinner and taller tiles. Click the preview button. If the page looks good, click the update button. The result is the image below. The final Contact Us content with 8 tiles aligned nicely.
CONTACT THE GOVERNOR With your concerns or comments. REQUEST A COMMEMORATIVE MESSAGE To recognize an occasion, organization or individual. REQUEST A MEETING For a personal meeting, group or media interview. INVITE THE GOVERNOR TO AN EVENT Request the Governor to attend your event. STATE CAPITOL TOURS Tour information SUBMIT A FLAG REQUEST To fly your flag above the Capitol and receive a Certificate of Authenticity. UIPA REQUEST Information to make a Uniform Information Practices Act request. GENERAL INFORMATION General contact details and links to related sites.
Disable the linked page after deleting tile After deleting a tile, you may have to disable the linked-to page. The links are out in the wild and constituents have bookmarked the link and will navigate to the page. To disable a page, set the linked-to page visibility to private. Click Edit. Click Private. Click OK. Click Update. The page visibility is now set to private. The public cannot view the page. Too Many Tiles Sometimes, the needs of the office will required more than 9 tiles. When that happens, the tiles are difficult to line up. When that happens, we have a weird alignment of tiles. The aesthetics will be weird. Unbalanced alignment 1. Unbalanced alignment 2. 2 rows with 5 tiles won’t work because the tiles will be too skinny. New tile design To create a new tile, you have to specify 4 parts. Here we look at the 4 parts of the Comments on Legislation tile. The bold red text is the destination URL when you click the tile. COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. The bold red text is the large text on the upper part of the tile. COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. The bold red text is an icon name. Some icons are listed at webpage https://governor.hawaii.gov/fonticons/. COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. The bold red text is the smaller text at the bottom of the tile. COMMENTS ON LEGISLATION Submit comments on legislation. Notes To change the default CSS, select Appearance > Theme Editor, select file style.css. DO NOT MODIFY THIS FILE OR ANY THEME FILE UNLESS YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING; YOU CAN BREAK THE WEBSITE. LIST OF NOMINEES Members of the public are invited to submit comments regarding judicial nominees until Monday, October 4, 2021. [gravityform id="27" title="false" description="true"]

Workflow Constituents who want to serve on a board applies at https://forms.ehawaii.gov/pages/board-survey/. The staff downloads an Excel file containing applications from website ???website name???. The Excel file is uploaded into GovCRM at app page https://govcrm.hawaii.gov/BoardApplication/Upload/. Applications are reviewed by the staff and the Governor. The Governor appoints the constituent to the board. Many applicants are approved by the Senate. Boards members have term limits. The Governor’s office is constantly looking for members to fill the board seats. GovCRM application To access the Boards module, click the Boards link at the top of the home page. The Boards module is available to users with the proper Active Directory security profile. If you do not see this option, contact your GovCRM administrator.
The Boards module lets you maintain information about boards, commissions, committees, and similar groups. You can track seat assignments and other information.
Board reports are available.
Boards and Commissions data SVG diagram showing Boards are connected to multiple Seats. Seats are connected to a current Member and multiple previous Members. Board Board of Agriculture Seat 1 Resident of the County of Kaua‘i Seat 2 Chairperson of the BLNR or Designee Current Member Kimo Kalani | Term 07/01/2020 - 06/30/2024 Previous Member John Q Smith | Term 07/01/2016 - 06/30/2020 Previous Member Janis Joplin | Term 07/01/2012 - 06/30/2016 The Governor nominates and appoints persons to more than 170 boards and commissions established by the State of Hawaiʻi Constitution, state statutes and executive orders. Each board has several seats. Each seat has a current member. This application will track the current member and previous members.
Boards list When you access the Boards module, the first page you see is a list of Boards and Commissions. The fields displayed are:
Board name Department code Termination date To view the Board Member data, click the right-arrow expander.
To view terminated boards, check the expired checkbox.
Click on a Board name to view or edit the Board data and Member data.
To create a new Board, click the create button at the bottom of the window.
TODO TODO: Track new applicants.
You can track nominations, appointments, referrals, seat assignments, and other information. You can also keep a complete history of correspondence with contacts and members.

body:
There are 2 Contact Us forms, Invite the Governor to an Event and Advance Information Sheet. When an event invitation is approved, an email is sent to the constituent with a link to the Advance Information Sheet form.
Invite the Governor to an Event https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/invite-the-governor-to-an-event/
Advance Information Sheet https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/event-ais/
When an event invitation is approved, a staffer send a GovCRM email to the constituent. The email from GovCRM contains a link to the Advance Information Sheet (AIS) form. The link has the Event ID in the query string. WordPress Gravity Forms will use the query string to automatically fill-in the Event ID and some other form fields. Each browser has limitations in the length of the query string and some fields may be left incomplete or blank.
The Event ID in the AIS is disabled (sort-of). To change the Event ID, click the Event Name field, then press the back-tab (shift-tab).

Click the email icon next to an email address.
This will open the email popup window. The email address is automatically filled-in.
The email templates are listed at the top of the popup window. Select an email template by clicking the radio button.
You may edit the email body, send-to email address, CC email address, and subject line.
You may add multiple email addresses separated with commas or semicolons. Do not remove [GM9999999] at the end of the subject line. This is used to track emails. Do not remove [[AISDATA]] in the email body. This automatically populates the Contact Us AIS form. When the email looks good, click the Preview button. The preview window opens.
You cannot edit in the preview window. Do not click the online form link in the preview because it will open the Contact Us AIS form and you’ll lose the email template window. When the application sends an email, you’re BCC’d a copy.

body:
Workflow Constituents submit a Invite the Governor to an Event from the Governor’s website https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/invite-the-governor-to-an-event/
Hourly, the WebJob processes the invitations. The invitation data is added to the GovCRM database and application.
Daily, the Events staff reviews the New events.
Determine if each event is valid and is appropriate for the Governor to attend.
Check the Governor’ schedule.
If the Governor will attend an event, email the constitutent an AIS request using the GovCRM email system.
Update the events data.
Close the Event.
The requirements are stated on the form:
Mahalo for inviting Governor Ige to your event. Your request will be reviewed upon receipt. All requests must be submitted at least four (4) weeks prior to the requested event date. Required fields are marked with a red asterisk (*) and MUST be filled in. Please note that we will be unable to process incomplete or inaccurate entries.
To access the Events module, click the Events link on the home page. The Event module is available to users with the proper Active Directory security profile. If you do not see this option, contact your GovCRM administrator.
Event reports are available.

body:
To access the Flags module, click the Flag Requests link on the home page. The Flags module is available to users with the proper Active Directory security profile. If you do not see this option, contact your GovCRM administrator.
Workflow Constituents submit a Flag Request from the Governor’s website https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/submit-a-flag-request/ The GovCRM application sends an alert email to distribution group gov.flagrequest@hawaiioimt.onmicrosoft.com. The distribution group owner may add or remove users. Contact the constituent to arrange for a flag to be dropped off at the office, either 3x5 or 4x6, U.S. flag or Hawaiʻi State flag. Add a note on drop-off date to GovCRM. Drop off the flag at the Sheriff’s office no more than two weeks ahead of the date to be flown and notify the Sheriffs that the flag must be flown on a certain day. Sheriff’s telephone number is 586-1356. Pick up the flag from the Sheriff’s office. Print a certificate of authenticity and upload a PDF copy to GovCRM. Notify the constituent to pickup the flag at the State Capitol. Close the record. The Flag Request requirements are stated on the Request form:
Flags delivered to the Office of the Governor according to the process outlined below will be flown above the State Capitol.
Flag Requirements: Only United States and Hawaii State flags measuring 3x5 ft. or 4x6 ft. will be flown at the Hawaii State Capitol. You must provide your own flag, and flags must be delivered to and picked up from the Office of the Governor. Flags may not be mailed to the Office of the Governor, and flags will not be returned from the Office of the Governor via mail.
Instructions: Complete the following form to submit your request. Each field marked with a red asterisk (*) is required. Please indicate if the flag is for a special occasion (retirement, birthday, anniversary, etc.) and the date you would like the flag to be flown (allow 5-10 working days from date of request). Military retirement requests should come from the retiree’s Career Counselor.

body:
The Commemorative Messages Admin (CM-Admin) staff person must assign GovCRM roles to Commemorative Messages staff. To be a CM-Admin, your IT administrator must assign you to Active Directory (AD) security group GovOfficeCRMCMAdmin. A list of all GovCRM roles are here.
Message List The first page is a list of all open messages. (Not CLOSED and not DECLINED.)
➔ Your assignments The first section of cases, Your assignments, will include cases that are assigned to you. If you have role ROUTER, the first section of cases will include New cases. If you have role COORDINATOR, the first section of cases will include cases assigned to the COORDINATOR role. If you have role ROUTER, the first section of cases will include cases assigned to the ROUTER role. Other work All open cases that are not in the first section will be listed in the second section, Other work. These are the cases that are Open and assigned to other people. Workflow The ROUTER selects a New case and decides to Approve or Decline the request.
Buttons The users with roles Coordinator or Router can see the buttons. Only the ROUTER sees the Approve button.
The Approve and Decline buttons are displayed only if the case status is New.
Approve request The ROUTER clicks the proc_details_approve_button.png button. A popup asks if you want to send the Approval email. If you click the Cancel button, the action is canceled.
A second popup gives you a second chance to cancel.
If you click the Approve button, an email is automatically sent to the constituent. And these steps occur:
Application sets the case status to ➔ Approved Application assigns the case to Role ➔ ROUTER Application adds words to the case activity log An email is automatically sent to the constituent. If there multiple email addresses associated with the constituent, the email is sent to all email addresses. If multiple constituents are associated with the request, the email is also sent to the additional constituents. The email is BCC’d to email distribution group Gov.Messages.Router@hawaiioimt.onmicrosoft.com. The email is BCC’d to you. The Approve and Decline buttons are removed. If the constituent submits the request 4 weeks early, the following email is sent. The delivery method determines the telephone number in the email body.
Aloha and thank you for contacting the Office of Governor David Ige. Your request for *message name* has been approved, and our team is working to complete the commemorative message by the due date indicated in your request. We will contact you if we have questions or need clarification. If you do not receive notice for pick-up within 3 days of your requested due date, please contact our office at 808-586-0034. Mahalo, Office of the Governor State of Hawaiʻi If the constituent submits a late request, the following email is sent.
Aloha and thank you for contacting the Office of Governor David Ige. We received your request for *message name* and will do our best to process it by the date indicated. Our team is working to complete commemorative messages on a timely basis, and requests submitted within the timeframe guidelines are given priority. We will contact you if we have questions or need clarification. In the meantime, please contact our office at 808-586-0034 if you have any questions. Mahalo, Office of the Governor State of Hawaiʻi Assign to a drafter The ROUTER clicks the Draft button. The ROUTER then selects a user to write a draft of the message.
You may enter an optional Draft due date. TODO: Add application enhancement to send an alert email when a case is past due.
Users who are assigned role “Commemorative Message Drafter” will appear in the Staff drop down list.
If this message is a RUSH, click the Rush checkbox. You must add a rush note. If there is no rush note, the RUSH is ignored. This note will appear at the top of the case details page.
Click the Select button. These steps occur:
Application sets the case status to ➔ Drafting. Application assigns the case to the selected User. (developer note: the assigned group is reset to null) Application adds words to the case activity log. An email is automatically sent to the “drafter”. The email is BCC’d to you. GovCRM Tasker - DRAFTING Job Kimo, you have been assigned a DRAFTING job. Link to DRAFTING JOB. Due date is Monday October 11, 2021. If the case is a “RUSH”, the following is sent:
GovCRM Tasker - RUSH Drafting Job RUSH Kimo, you have been assigned a RUSH drafting job. Rush note. Due date is Monday October 11, 2021. Link to DRAFTING JOB. Drafter uploads document The drafter clicks the Upload Draft button. The document should be a DOCX file.
If the filename ends with “FINAL”

Activity Log Status > old Status Group > blank Attachment Type > MESSAGE Upload PDF Activity Log Status > PDF Uploaded Group > COORDINATOR If the file is not a PDF, the document is not saved and an error message is displayed. body:
The GovCRM application is secured by Azure Active Directory.
Local on-prem active directory in hawaii.local GOVOU has security groups for this application.
The AD security groups can be assigned to these staff users:
Boards and Commissions Casework Commemorative Messages Events with the Governor Flag Requests Meetings with the Governor Admin/Config A new staff person is added to AD group GovOfficeCRM plus one or more of the other security groups. When the staff person leaves, remove the person from the Active Directory security groups.
List of Active Directory Security Groups AD Security Group Description GovOfficeCRM Access to HOME page and Legislative Comments (Everyone should belong to this group.) GovOfficeCRMBNC Boards and Commissions Regular Users (edit) GovOfficeCRMBNCViewer Boards and Commissions Read Only (read only) GovOfficeCRMCasesAdmin Casework Administrators (admin) GovOfficeCRMCasesUser Casework Regular Users (edit) GovOfficeCRMCM Commemorative Messages Read Only (read only) GovOfficeCRMCMAdmin Commemorative Messages Administrators (admin) GovOfficeCRMCMUser Commemorative Messages Regular Users (edit) GovOfficeCRMConfigUser Configuration Administrator GovOfficeCRMFlagsAdmin Flag Request Administrators (admin) GovOfficeCRMFlagsUser Flag Request Regular Users (edit) GovOfficeCRMGEAdmin Gov Events Admin (admin) GovOfficeCRMGEUser Gov Events User (edit) GovOfficeCRMGEViewer Gov Events Read Only (read only) GovOfficeCRMMtgAdmin Gov Meeting Requests Administrators (admin) GovOfficeCRMMtgUser Gov Meeting Requests Regular Users (edit) GovOfficeCRMMtgViewer Gov Meeting Requests Read Only (read only) GovOfficeCRMAdmin not used GovOfficeCRMCMCoord deprecated GovOfficeCRMCMEdit deprecated GovOfficeCRMMtgFiltered deprecated GovOfficeCRMSurveyAdmin GovOfficeCRMSurveyUser There are matching AD groups with names that start with GovOfficeDEVCRM. These are used for https://govcrm-staging.azurewebsites.us/.
TODO: Update C# code so that only one AD group is needed.
Commemorative Messages roles Commemorative Messages staff also are assigned GovCRM roles. These roles are explained at the Commemorative Messages Roles page.
Active Directory groups are assigned by your IT Administrator. Commemorative Message roles are assigned by your staff Commemorative Messages admin.
When a staffer leaves, keep the username in the database table. The name is used in reports. You may set the user as inactive. Developer Notes Create Active Directory groups. Create Application roles in Azure Active Directory App Registration. Assign Active Directory groups to Application roles. Use Application role in C# code. There is a one-to-one relationship between Active Directory groups and Application roles.
Application roles Display the list of Application roles by clicking “App roles”.
To create a new Application role, click the Create app role button.
Fill in the Role Display name, Value, and Description. Then click the Apply button.
Assign Active Directory group to Application role https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/howto-add-app-roles-in-azure-ad-apps
Under Manage, select Users and groups. Select Add user/group to open the Add Assignment pane.
Select Users and groups in the Add Assignment pane. A list of users and security groups is displayed. You can search for GovCRM™ groups by entering “govofficecrm” in the search box. Select the AD group from the list. Click the Select button to proceed.
Select Select a role in the Add assignment pane. All the roles that you’ve defined for the application are displayed. The role descriptions are displayed. Choose a role and click the Select button.
Select the Assign button to finish the assignment of groups to the app.
Confirm that the groups you added appear in the Users and groups list.
This the complete list.

Application User data fields:
Username - Required - User’s email address. This is the magic key. The Username MUST match the user’s email address. Last Name First Name Middle Name Display Name - Required - First name plus last name. Initials - Required - This can be a nickname or first name. Email - Required - Must match the Username. Telephone - Required - Required but not used. (yet) Island - Required Time Zone On the right-side of the screen are GovCRM roles.

The CM-Router/CM-Coordinator/CM-Supervisor clicks the Draft button. A dialog pops up with the Writers in the dropdown list. Staffers assigned role Commemorative Message Drafter appear in the dropdown list.

body:
Website Constituents will submit comments or requests to the Governor’s website, https://governor.hawaii.gov/contact-us/.
The Contact Us webpage contains several tiles. The number of tiles will vary, depending on the needs of the office. The WebJob is concerned with only some tiles. Clicking on a tile will open a WordPress Page containing a Gravity Forms form.
Gravity Forms The Governor’s website Contact Us webpage has multiple tiles with links to Gravity Forms forms. Clicking on a tile will open a WordPress Page containing a Gravity Forms form.
Here are the Gravity Forms on the WordPress administration page. There are two pages of forms. If a form is toggled green , then it is active.
Do not delete an inactive form if it has data entries.
List of current forms 2020 October 10
Form ID Form Name XML Template ID WordPress Page ID 24 Bill Signing Ceremony Request 110 23002 9 Comments on Legislation COL 4582 27 Comments regarding Judicial Nominees none 25639 1 Contact the Governor CTG3 188 21 Event Advance Information Sheet 135 16673 28 Event Invitation 130 402 32 Request a Commemorative Message plus Event Invitation 902 422 3 Request a Meeting 354 3939 7 Submit a Flag Request 348 3966 11 Contact the First Lady 120 754 31 Invite the First Lady to an Event 130FL 754 Gravity Form XML Notification If an active form has an XML notification, then we need WebJob code to process the XML.
The weirdo Notification name “XML To IQ GFUEANZ” was a requirement of an older version of Gravity Forms. The newer version of Gravity Forms does not require the “GFUEANZ” to email the attachment files in the Notification. You may rename the Notification.
When the constituent submits a form, Gravity Forms will send an email to officeofthegovernor@hawaii.gov. The email contains XML data.
Exchange The WebJob uses the Microsoft Exchange Web Services to sign-in to the officeofthegovernor@hawaii.gov email account.
Job Schedule The project contains file Settings.job. The content of this file is a JSON formatted crontab. Here is the content:
{ "schedule": "0 0 7-20 * * 1-6" } This is a cron schedule. Note: this cron schedule has a seconds value.
The WebJob will execute at the times listed in the cron schedule.
Config The application configuration values are kept in the Azure configuration section and project file app.config.

body:
Create the application database. In this example, the database name is govhawaiicrmdb.
CREATE DATABASE govhawaiicrmdb In the master database, create a database login for the application. In this example, the database login is databaseusername. Choose a strong password.
USE [master]
CREATE LOGIN databaseusername WITH PASSWORD='secretpassword'; In the application database, create a user for the application.
USE [govhawaiicrmdb]
CREATE USER databaseusername FROM LOGIN databaseusername; Grant some database roles to the database user.
exec sp_addrolemember 'db_datareader', 'databaseusername'; exec sp_addrolemember 'db_datawriter', 'databaseusername'; Download the SQL script SQL_GovCRM.sql.txt from DevOps repo https://dev.azure.com/yoshiakiiinuma/_git/GovHawaiiSQL.
The SQL script creates the tables, views, user-defined functions, and stored procedures. At the end of the file, there are many “GRANT SELECT” and “GRANT EXECUTE” statements. You’ll have to change the username in the script to your databaseusername.
Execute SQL scripts:
The IT Administrator shall load up the zipcode and country tables.
InitializeData_country.sql InitializeData_zipcode.sql The IT Administrator shall load the default email header and email footer records into the email template table. Update these 2 records when the ADMINISTRATION (Governor) changes. If multiple headers/footers are needed then add and update the application C# code to use multiple header/footers.
InitializeData_emailheader.sql The IT Administrator shall load the default system appuser record. This a single record. This record is not used except for appearing in reports.
InitializeData_appuser.sql The IT Administrator may load these other tables. There are GovCRM pages for this but the scripts are easier.
InitializeData_approle.sql InitializeData_boardtype.sql InitializeData_boardcategory.sql

body:
Microsoft Graph permissions https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/permissions-reference
Microsoft Graph permission names follow a simple pattern: resource.operation.constraint. For example, User.Read grants permission to read the profile of the signed-in user, User.ReadWrite grants permission to read and modify the profile of the signed-in user, and Mail.Send grants permission to send mail on behalf of the signed-in user.
The constraint element of the name determines the potential extent of access your app will have within the directory. Currently Microsoft Graph supports the following constraints:
All grants permission for the app to perform the operations on all of the resources of the specified type in a directory. For example, User.Read.All potentially grants the app privileges to read the profiles of all of the users in a directory. Shared grants permission for the app to perform the operations on resources that other users have shared with the signed-in user. This constraint is mainly used with Outlook resources like mail, calendars, and contacts. For example, Mail.Read.Shared, grants privileges to read mail in the mailbox of the signed-in user as well as mail in mailboxes that other users in the organization have shared with the signed-in user. AppFolder grants permission for the app to read and write files in a dedicated folder in OneDrive. This constraint is only exposed on Files permissions and is only valid for Microsoft accounts. -If no constraint is specified the app is limited to performing the operations on the resources owned by the signed-in user. For example, User.Read grants privileges to read the profile of the signed-in user only, and Mail.Read grants permission to read only mail in the mailbox of the signed-in user. Note: In delegated scenarios, the effective permissions granted to your app may be constrained by the privileges of the signed-in user in the organization.
Images are resized to fit the screen. To see a larger image, right-click and select “Open image in new tab”.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-service
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-user
Get access without a user Some apps call Microsoft Graph with their own identity and not on behalf of a user. In many cases, these apps are background services or daemons that run on a server without the presence of a signed-in user. An example of such an app might be an email archival service that wakes up and runs overnight. In some cases, apps that have a signed-in user present may also need to call Microsoft Graph under their own identity. For example, an app may need to use functionality that requires more elevated privileges in an organization than the signed-in user may have.
Apps that call Microsoft Graph with their own identity use the OAuth 2.0 client credentials grant flow to get access tokens from Azure AD. This describes the basic steps to configure a service and use the OAuth client credentials grant flow to get an access token.
Register your app. Configure permissions for Microsoft Graph on your app. Get administrator consent. Get an access token. Use the access token to call Microsoft Graph. Setup Application Access Policy. Register your app You must first register your app at the Azure Active Directory app registration portal.
Click on the new registration name.
Click Add a permission button.
Click the large Microsoft Graph button.
Click the Application permissions button.
Select Mail.Read and Mail.Send checkboxes.
Click the Add permissions button.
Click Grant admin consent.
Repeat for SharePoint permissions.
Certificates & secrets Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) supports two types of authentication: password-based authentication (client secret) and certificate-based authentication. It’s recommended that your application use a certificate.
Client Secret To create a client secret, click the button. Enter a single line description. Select the secret lifespan. Click the Add button.
Copy the secret value now. You cannot view the secret value after leaving the webpage.
X509 certificate Select Certificates & secrets from left menu. Click Upload Certificate button.
Create a self-signed public certificate https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/howto-create-self-signed-certificate
Using PowerShell:
Use a self-signed certificate only for Development or Testing, not Production.
$certname = "{certificateName}" ## Replace {certificateName} $cert = New-SelfSignedCertificate -Subject "CN=$certname" -CertStoreLocation "Cert:\CurrentUser\My" -KeyExportPolicy Exportable -KeySpec Signature -KeyLength 2048 -KeyAlgorithm RSA -HashAlgorithm SHA256 Export-Certificate -Cert $cert -FilePath "C:\Users\yourusername\Desktop\$certname.cer" ## Specify your preferred location TODO: FINISH THIS UP SOON.
Scoping application permissions to specific Exchange Online mailboxes In the images below, replace whirata.onmicrosoft.com with hawaii.gov.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-limit-mailbox-access
Administrators who want to limit the app access to a specific set of mailboxes can use the New-ApplicationAccessPolicy PowerShell cmdlet to configure access control.
Get the app’s Application (client) ID from the Azure app registration. Create a mail-enabled security group. Create an application access policy. Identify the app’s Application (client) ID Open the Azure Active Directory portal. Go to your app’s App registration. The Application ID is listed near the top of the overview.
https://aad.portal.azure.com/#blade/Microsoft_AAD_RegisteredApps/ApplicationMenuBlade/Overview/appId/900f9389-477a-4f71-878e-87ffa10f6e82/isMSAApp/
Setup Exchange Mail-Enabled Security Group Open the Exchange Admin Center. Select the Groups option. Click the Add a group button. Choose group type Mail-enabled security. Enter a name for your group. Enter a description. Enter an email address. Check the Require owner approval to join the group checkbox. Click the Create group button. Click the Close button. The new group is now in the Group listing. Select the new group and add new member test.govazure@hawaii.gov. In the Exchange Admin Center, click the Add a group button.
Choose group type Mail-enabled security.
Enter a name for your group. Enter a description.
Enter an email address. Check the Require owner approval to join the group checkbox.
Click the Create group button.
Click the Close button.
The new group is now in the Group listing.
Select the new group. Add new member test.govazure@hawaii.gov.
Create an Application Access Policy using PowerShell You can get a listing of your Application Access Policies.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-applicationaccesspolicy
Open PowerShell. Import the Exchange PowerShell module. Connect to Exchange with modern authentication. Create new Application Access Policy. Test the policy with various email accounts. The AccessCheckResult will be Granted or Denied. PowerShell error message, click here. PS> Import-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement PS> Connect-ExchangeOnline -UserPrincipalName yourname@hawaii.gov PS> Get-ApplicationAccessPolicy PS> New-ApplicationAccessPolicy -AppId 900f9389-477a-4f71-878e-87ffa10f6e82 -PolicyScopeGroupId govcrmtestsecuritygroup@whirata.onmicrosoft.com -AccessRight RestrictAccess -Description "Restrict this app to members of distribution group GovCRM_TEST_MailSecurityGroup." PS> Test-ApplicationAccessPolicy -Identity graphtest@whirata.onmicrosoft.com -AppId 900f9389-477a-4f71-878e-87ffa10f6e82 PS> Test-ApplicationAccessPolicy -Identity whirata@whirata.onmicrosoft.com -AppId 900f9389-477a-4f71-878e-87ffa10f6e82 Here is an image of the PowerShell session with the steps to setup the new Application Access Policy. body:
This documentation was created with the Hugo static website generator and the Google Docsy theme.
https://gohugo.io/
https://www.docsy.dev/
GovCRM Documentation Setup Install Visual Code Install Git Install Node Install Hugo Install Go compiler Clone the project from version control Install Visual Studio Code https://code.visualstudio.com/
You may use any plain text editor. You do not have to use Visual Studio Code.
Install Git https://git-scm.com/download/win
You should set the global default user name and user email address.
git config --global user.name "Mr. Peabody" git config --global user.email "hector.j.peabody@govhawaii.com" Install Node.js https://nodejs.org/en/
Installing node will also install npm.
Install Hugo Install the latest extended version. The Docsy theme requires the extended version.
Hugo releases are in GitHub. This link will get you to the lastest release: https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases.
Download the latest extended version. The extended version is near the bottom of the list.
Copy file hugo.exe to a directory in your PATH. I like directory C:\Users\yourusername\AppData\Local\Programs\Hugo\bin. And add this directory to your user path environment variable.
set PATH "%PATH%;C:\Users\yourusername\AppData\Local\Programs\Hugo\bin" Install Go compiler https://go.dev/dl/
Clone the repo git clone https://waynerhiratahawaiigov.visualstudio.com/GovCRM%20Documentation/_git/GovCRM%20Documentation yournewdirectoryname Install these 3 node modules.
cd yournewdirectoryname npm install -D autoprefixer npm install -D postcss-cli npm install -D postcss If you have older version of the node packages, you may update the packages:
npm update -D postcss npm update -D autoprefixer npm update -D postcss-cli To update the Docsy Hugo module:
hugo mod get -u github.com/google/docsy Verify your git username and email for this repo:
git config user.name git config user.email If you want to set your local git name and email for this repo:
git config user.name "Homer J. Simpson" git config user.email "homer.j.simpson@hawaii.gov" If you are missing directory node_modules npm install Edit the documentation files The documentation source files are in directories
content static The configuration values are in file
config.toml To build the website:
hugo The output is in directory public.
Before you build, delete the public directory. Hugo does not delete old files in the public directory and you end up with some junk in your public directory.
If the build fails, you may have to delete the Hugo Module cache. All of your dependencies will be re-downloaded next time you execute “hugo”.
hugo mod clean NEW ADMINISTRATION Update the configuration file config.toml. Update [params.links.user] sections. The social media links at the footer of all pages should be for the current governor websites. Or remove such uselessness.
